%text If $\tan^{-1}x = \theta$ then $\theta\in\prng$ - the principal range of $\tan^{-1} x$ But $\angb > \pi$ and therefore $\angb\notin\prng$ Recall however that $\tan \left(\pi+\theta \right)=\tan\theta$. Which means that % \begin{align}
\tan \left(\angb \right) &= \tan \left(\pi + \angc \right) = \tan\angc \\ \text{Also }\angc&\in \prng \\ \therefore \tan^{-1} \left(\tan\angb \right) &= \tan^{-1} \left(\tan\angc \right) \\ &= \angc \end{align} %text %
